Title: Does every non-trivial path in the plane pass through either a rational point or an irrational point?
Content: Does every non-trivial path in $\mathbb{R}^2$ pass through a point of $(\mathbb{Q} \times \mathbb{Q}) \cup (\mathbb{I} \times \mathbb{I})$ ? The topology is the usual Euclidean. My intuition says yes, but no idea how to show that. I use this as part of a counterexample to another problem. Edit after correct answer: This problem is equivalent to whether $(\mathbb{Q} \times \mathbb{I}) \cup (\mathbb{I} \times \mathbb{Q})$ is totally path-disconnected. The accepted answer can also be used to show the stronger statement that $(\mathbb{Q} \times \mathbb{I}) \cup (\mathbb{I} \times \mathbb{Q})$ is totally separated (which implies totally disconnected).
AcceptedAnswer: Write $X$ for your set of rational points union irrational points. Yes, every nonconstant path in $\mathbb{R}^2$ hits $X$ . Note that any "rational line" $t\mapsto (q_1 + q_2t, q_3 +  q_4t)$ (where $q_i \in \mathbb{Q} \setminus\{0\}$ ) has image in $X$ . Assuming your path $\gamma\colon[0,1]\to \mathbb{R^2}$ is nonconstant, assume $\gamma(a) \neq \gamma(b)$ . Then there is a rational line separating $\gamma(a)$ and $\gamma(b)$ , so by the intermediate value theorem, $\gamma$ must hit that rational line, and must thereby hit $X$ . To produce such a rational line separating your two points $\gamma(a)$ and $\gamma(b)$ , choose close enough rational approximations for each point, then use the perpendicular bisector of the rational approximations.
